content.p: Candace is applying to two colleges, Ross College and the more prestigious Cirus College. The probability table below represents her belief about whether she will be accepted. We use the following notation:
R—the event of being accepted to Ross College
C—the event of being accepted to Cirus College

image.alt: table of probabilities of acceptance to two different colleges

body.p: What does Candace believe is the probability that she'll be accepted to both colleges?

response.feedback: Incorrect. P("not R" and "not C") = 0.23 is the probability that she is not accepted at either college.

Incorrect. You may have applied the complement rule and calculated 1 − P("not R" and "not C") = 1 − 0.23 = 0.77. But this is incorrect because the complement of the event ("not R" and "not C") is "accepted by at least one of the two colleges," not "accepted at both colleges."
Incorrect. The probability of an event can never be greater than 1.
Correct. P(R and C) = 0.38 is the probability that she is accepted by Ross and by Cirus.
Incorrect. 0.40 is P(C), the probability that she gets accepted by Cirus. The probability that she gets accepted by both is included in this event, so the probability is less than 0.40.

body.p: What does Candace believe is the probability that she will only get into Ross College?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You have identified P("not R" and C), which is the probability that she will only get into Cirus.
Correct. The probability that she will only get into Ross is P(R and "not C").
Incorrect. You have identified P(R and C), which is the probability that she will only get into both Ross and Cirus.

Incorrect. You may have identified P(not C), which is the probability that she will not get into Cirus. This is incorrect because it includes the situation in which she gets into Ross and the situation in which she does not get into Ross.
Incorrect. You have identified P(R), which is the probability that she will get into Ross. This is incorrect because it includes the situation in which she also gets into Cirus.

body.p: What does Candace believe is the probability that she will only get into Cirus College?

response.feedback: Correct. The probability that she will only get into Cirus is P("not R" and C).

Incorrect. You have identified P(not R), which is the probability that she will not get into Ross. This is incorrect because it includes the situation in which she gets into Cirus and the situation in which she does not get into Cirus.
You have identified P(R and "not C"), which is the probability that she will only get into Ross.
Incorrect. You have identified P(R and C), which is the probability that she will only get into both Ross and Cirus.
Incorrect. You have identified P(C), which is the probability that she will get into Cirus. This is incorrect because it includes the event "R and C."

body.p: What does Candace believe is the probability that she'll be accepted to exactly one of the colleges?

response.feedback: Incorrect. 0.38 is P(R and C), the probability that she gets into both colleges. This is incorrect because the outcome (R and C) is not in the sample space for the event "accepted to exactly one college." What outcomes describe "accepted to exactly one college"?

Incorrect. You may have applied the complement rule and calculated 1 − P("not R" and "not C) = 1 − 0.23 = 0.77. But this is incorrect because the complement of the event ("not R" and "not C") is "accepted by at least one of the two colleges," not "accepted by exactly one of the two colleges."

Correct. If Candace is accepted to exactly one college, then she is accepted to only Ross or only Cirus. These are disjoint events, so P(accepted to exactly one college) = P(R and "not C") + P("not R" and C) = 0.37 + 0.02 = 0.39.

Incorrect. You may have applied the complement rule and calculated 1 − P(R and C) = 1 − 0.38 = 0.62. This is incorrect because the complement of the event (R and C) is "accepted by at most one college," not "accepted by exactly one of the two colleges."
Incorrect. 0.37 is P(R and "not C"), the probability that she gets into Ross only. There is another outcome you need to consider.

body.p: What does Candace believe is the probability that she'll be accepted to at least one of the colleges (i.e., to Ross College or Cirus College or both)?

response.feedback: Correct. Since we are using a probability table, the most obvious approach is to think of the sample space of the event "accepted by at least one of the colleges" as {R and C, R and "not C", "not R" and C}, which are disjoint events. So add 0.38 + 0.37 + 0.02 = 0.77. Another strategy views "accepted by at least one of the colleges" as the complement of the event ("not R" and "not C"). Using the complement rule, 1 − P("not R" and "not C") = 1 − 0.23 = 0.77. You can also use the General Addition Rule: P(R) + P(C) − P(R and C) = 0.75 + 0.40 − 0.38 = 0.77.
Incorrect. The probability cannot be 1 because there is one outcome in the table that is not in the sample space for the event "accepted by at least one college."

Incorrect. 0.38 is P(R and C), the probability that she gets into both colleges. This is incorrect because the outcome (R and C) is only part of the sample space for the event "accepted to at least one college." What other outcomes will be part of the sample space?

Incorrect. The probability of an event can never be greater than 1. You may have tried to calculate the probability of "Ross College or Cirus College or both" by adding P(R) + P(C) + P(R and C). This is incorrect since P(R and C) is included in the other two probabilities. Recall that "or" statements with events that are not disjoint require use of the General Addition Rule.

Incorrect. You may have applied the complement rule and calculated 1 – P(R and C) = 1 − 0.38 = 0.62. This is incorrect because the complement of the event (R and C) is "accepted by at most one college," not "accepted by at least one of colleges." The complement rule will work here if you correctly identify the complement events.

body.p: What does Candace believe is the probability that she'll be accepted by neither of the colleges?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You may have interpreted "accepted by neither college" as the event ("not C" or "not R") and calculated P(not C) + P(not R) = 0.60 + 0.25, but this is incorrect because "accepted by neither college" is the event ("not C" and "not R").
Correct. "Accepted by neither college" is the event ("not C" and "not R"), which is 0.23.

Incorrect. You may have interpreted "accepted by neither college" as the event ("not C" or "not R") and calculated P(not C) + P(not R) − P("not C" and "not R) = 0.60 + 0.25 − 0.23, but this is incorrect because "accepted by neither college" is the event ("not C" AND "not R").

Incorrect. Did you add 0.37 and 0.02? If so, you calculated the probability that Candace is accepted at only one college (only R or only C). You need to calculate the probability that she is not accepted at either college.
Incorrect. 0.38 is P(C and R), which is the probability that she is accepted by both colleges.
